title: Nuxt 3.8
description: Nuxt 3.8 is out, bringing built-in DevTools, automatic Nuxt Image install, a new app manifest and much more.

children.value: Just to remind you, we're now using
You can now install a module with
We now share the same port with the Vite websocket, meaning better support for docker containers in development.
Nuxt DevTools v1.0.0 is out and we now think it's ready to be shipped as a direct dependency of Nuxt.
Check out Nuxt DevTools v1.0 announcement.
the first time that they are used (
if you're using images in your site; it can apply optimisations to make your site more performant.
This is a behaviour change so do take care with this one.
We now support scanning layouts within subfolders in
in the same way as we do with
We now support a built-in app manifest (see
, if a site is generated with
route rules is supported for now; they will now redirect when performing client-side navigation.

children.value: <!-- Will be redirected to /about-us on client-side -->
The app manifest also enables future enhancements including detection of a new deployment by checking
opt-on from this behaviour if you need to
We now define a 'scope' for Nuxt composables executed in plugins (
), which allows running synchronous cleanup before navigating away from your site, using the Vue
This should fix an edge case with cookies (
) and also improves memory management such as Pinia stores (
Read more about Vue effect scopes.
). In case you're unaware, we support native async context on Node and Bun, enabled with

children.value: Once we have cross-runtime support, we will enable it by default.
Today, you can cutomize the options for the built-in
This can enable you to enforce trailing slash behaviour across your entire site, for example:

children.value: We have two very significant new features for
to prevent deep reactivity on the

). It should be a performance improvement if you are returning large arrays or objects. The object will still update when refetched; it just won't trigger reactive effects if you change a property deep within the
option to handle custom caching for these composables (

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight
props.code:
<script setup>
const nuxtApp = useNuxtApp()
const { data } = await useAsyncData(() => { /* fetcher */ }, {
  // this will not refetch if the key exists in the payload
  getCachedData: key => nuxtApp.payload.static[key] ?? nuxtApp.payload.data[key]
})
</script>

children.value: // this will not refetch if the key exists in the payload

We also support configuring some default values for these composables in an app-wide way (

props.className: language-ts shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight

children.value: We now more carefully load layer plugins (
) in the order of the layers, always loading your own plugins and middleware last. This should mean you can rely on utilities that layers may inject.
And probably one of the most significant changes - if you are using remote layers we now clone these within your
) so layers can use dependencies with your project. See
We've also added a test suite to cover these layer resolution changes.

branch of Nuxt is automatically deployed to a new release, for easier testing before releases. We've renamed this from the 'edge release channel' to the 'nightly release channel' to avoid confusion with
. And probably also with Microsoft Edge (though I haven't heard that anyone was confused with that one!)
Nitro v2.7 has been released with lots of improvements and bug fixes.
🔥 One of the most significant is that we now save
). So if possible, we'd recommend you update your Node version to at least 18.
Check out Nitro v2.7 release note.
This is likely to need code changes in your project.
Vue requires that type imports be explicit (so that the Vue compiler can correctly optimise and resolve type imports for props and so on). See
We've therefore taken the decision to turn on
by default in Nuxt projects, which will throw a type error if types are imported without an explicit
import. To resolve it you will need to update your imports:

props.className: language-diff shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight
props.code:
- import { someFunction, SomeOptions } from 'some-library'
+ import { someFunction } from 'some-library'
+ import type { SomeOptions } from 'some-library'

children.value: You may also encounter modules in the Nuxt ecosystem that need to be updated; please open an issue for those modules. I'm also very happy to help if you're encountering any problems with this, if you're a module author. Just tag me and I'll take a look.
If for whatever reason you need to undo this change in your project you can set the following configuration:

props.className: language-ts shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight

children.value: However, we'd recommend only doing that temporarily, as Vue does need this option to be set for best results.
As usual, our recommendation for upgrading is to run:

props.className: language-sh shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight

children.value: Read the full release notes of Nuxt
Thank you for reading this far! We hope you enjoy the new release. Please do let us know if you have any feedback or issues.

html .light .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-light);background: var(--shiki-light-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-light-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-light-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-light-text-decoration);}html.light .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-light);background: var(--shiki-light-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-light-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-light-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-light-text-decoration);}html .default .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-default);background: var(--shiki-default-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-default-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-default-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-default-text-decoration);}html .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-default);background: var(--shiki-default-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-default-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-default-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-default-text-decoration);}html .dark .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-dark);background: var(--shiki-dark-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-dark-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-dark-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-dark-text-decoration);}html.dark .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-dark);background: var(--shiki-dark-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-dark-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-dark-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-dark-text-decoration);}
